title: Remembering John Virgo: From Snooker Champion to Broadcasting Icon
summary: John Virgo, a renowned snooker legend and BBC commentator, has passed away at the age of 79. His professional career spanned 18 years, during which he achieved significant success, including winning the UK Championship and reaching the semi-finals of the World Championship in 1979. After retiring from playing in 1994, Virgo transitioned to broadcasting, becoming a beloved BBC commentator known for his insightful analysis and memorable catchphrase, 'where's the cue ball going?' He gained widespread fame as the presenter of the popular TV show Big Break alongside comedian Jim Davidson from 1991 to 2002. Virgo's last commentary was for the Masters final 17 days before his death. The snooker community has expressed deep sorrow, with players like Ronnie O'Sullivan and Mark Selby paying tribute to his character and influence. Additionally, Virgo entertained fans through exhibition matches featuring trick shots and impressions, cementing his legacy as a multifaceted figure in the sport.

background_read: John Virgo was a key figure in snooker, a cue sport popular in the UK and globally. He rose to prominence in the 1970s and 1980s as a competitive player, winning the UK Championship, one of the sport's top events. After his playing days, he became a broadcaster, helping to popularize snooker through TV shows like Big Break and commentary roles. His catchphrase and entertaining style made him a household name. Virgo's death marks the loss of a veteran who contributed to snooker's growth and community, as evidenced by tributes from current stars. Understanding his career highlights the evolution of snooker from a sport to a media spectacle.
